rationale: Muscle protein synthesis maximized when protein is spread across meals every 3–4 hours
Each meal should deliver ~0.4 g/kg protein

timing.breakfast: High-protein + carbs to start MPS early
timing.pre_workout: Moderate protein + low-GI carbs (1–3 hrs before training)
timing.evening_meal: Slow-digesting protein (casein) before bed to support overnight recovery

evidence: Areta et al. (2013). Four protein feedings/day > 2 feedings for lean mass gains. J Physiol.
Mamerow et al. (2014). Even distribution of protein improves muscle growth vs. skewed intake. J Nutr.
Schoenfeld & Aragon (2018). Optimal protein distribution for MPS. J Int Soc Sports Nutr.

rationale: Moderate frequency helps control hunger and adherence

timing.breakfast: Protein + fiber to prevent mid-morning hunger
timing.peri_workout: Protein around training; carbs optional depending on deficit size

evidence: Schoenfeld et al. (2015). Meal frequency (2–6/day) has little impact on fat loss if calories are matched. Nutrients.
Paddon-Jones & Leidy (2014). Higher protein at meals preserves lean mass during caloric deficit. Am J Clin Nutr.

rationale: Supports energy balance, metabolic health, and micronutrient sufficiency
Moderate spacing maintains blood glucose stability

timing.breakfast: Protein + whole grains + fruit to stabilize glucose
timing.dinner: Protein + vegetables + healthy fats for recovery and satiety
timing.snacks: Optional; fruits, nuts, dairy, protein sources

evidence: Farshchi et al. (2004). Consistent meal timing linked to better metabolic health. Am J Clin Nutr.
Jakubowicz et al. (2013). Balanced energy distribution improves glycemic control. Obesity.
